par.text: Bromine is a non-metal. Under normal conditions it is a brown, volatile liquid with a pungent, choking odour; it severely irritates the mucous membranes of the respiratory tract.
Bromine is poisonous and may cause burns. It dissolves in water to produce bromine water, used in laboratories as an oxidising agent. Its name is derived from the Greek word
- stink. Bromine was discovered and prepared by a French chemist, Antoine Jerome Balard, in 1826.
